title: TalkBank within CLARIN
segmentation: I feel a little guilty about being a member of Klaring because it makes the map expand.
I don't know if you've seen the map of Clarion and you have these nice little spots in Europe and it would be a very pretty map, but then suddenly you have this place over in North America.
And that makes it so Europe gets much smaller, so maybe I would suggest we take away the Atlantic.
And that would, you know, we could do that sort of cut it like a little piece of rip up the piece of paper on the map there.
But anyway, we are at CMU in Pittsburgh in the talk bank center.
Actually a Clarion B center, but I guess the only one outside of Europe.

So I thought it would be good to sort of explain, well, you know and and discuss what is the relation between talk bank and clotting and how can we you know interoperate better and what resources we have.
You know what we're really doing in in the talk bank project?
So you know, we really are addressing on the generally more cycle linguistic questions.
I'm a psycholinguist, and so the work has been cycle linguistically motivated.
Also, though some socio linguistic questions and you know these very basic issues about language, how is it learned and even how it has evolved?
But probably most of the data is on the language learning language usage, side all spoken language, so we really not.
Really, focusing on text text corpora, except in one of these projects, which actually I had a poster on yesterday.
So.
The areas that we have been covering, the area that we began with with child language.
We have the child's data system, child language data exchange system that has extended into several other areas in child language.
The fan bank is a new project that looks specifically a child phonologie development.
There's also a lock in narrative.
An bilingual has child language development has been a very big area in the last maybe.
Might say 10 years.

A second kind of line of database development is in clinical applications, which is, I think Interestingly, almost totally absent within chlorine, so that might be a really interesting kind of area to discuss, you know, and you would say, well, maybe that's not humanities, but it is.
It may be more social science, but it's also very much applied to health professions, speech and hearing, and so on.
So we have aphasia bank.
It's about 10 years old now.
Our brand new project called Fluency Bank, which would look at things like stuttering but also other disfluencies in Parkinson and so on.
And in second language learning and actually in children in general.
So so actually we all have disfluencies so so that you know it's it's really something that can be studied.
Quite generally, but there are, you know, specific fluency problems in certain cases.
While studying is the obvious one.
Dementia is sort of under resourced right now, but we probably will be doing more in that area and a rather large growing database in traumatic brain injury.
So all these are different clinical issues are related.
Often some of the same symptoms occur within aphasia.
You also have a proxy of speech and.
And other types of language disorders really.
So 1/3 area is monolingual adult language here.
See a bank allowed in conversation analysis, specifically one bank that it was in decay Clarion called some color bank is the conversation Bank of Danish.
We also have things in class bank, studying classroom interactions and some mild set of of.
No resources for gesture study.
Then there's a general area of multilingualism.
The bilingual Bilingue bank and SL a bank are growing quite rapidly, and there's also maybe not so much corpus development, but sort of online methods for instruction.
That sort of maybe outside of what Klaring is currently doing, but might be something that Clarin wouldn't consider getting into in the future is actually online resources for language learning.
OK, so those are within.
Those areas we have some projects funded right now.
For example there is no funding for the CIA work, but you know, people are very interested in it and the funding is mostly from the National Institute of Health but also from NSF.
And then we have that one project I discussed yesterday which is the National Endowment for the Humanities and the Deutsche Fleshtones Gazette shaft for the German part.
And so it's interesting to look at this to compare the child's project which has been running for 28 years.
And in terms of millions of words, you know something like almost 60,000,000 words, perhaps more about 3 terabytes of media data.
Much of this is linked to the transcript, so audio video is linked on the sentence level to the transcripts 41 languages.
And then I think probably the most important thing from clouding to think about is the number of publications that have been based on this database is 7000, perhaps more growing all the time.

Of course, the older the project, the more the you know, the more you're going to have, but I think the client really has to consider how many publications are really coming from the work, and I think they're probably more than than people realize when you when you get into thinking about all the ways in which current resources are used.
And the number of users numbers of web hits were up to 4 million.
Now since we began measuring in 2003, probably somewhat more.
But you know the curve of web hips is really, really almost exponential, and so these same numbers then apply with for the more recent projects.
Sometimes lower numbers, for example, fan bank really does have a large number, but you know this most recent project.

So these things you know change quite quickly, but it's worth looking at these facts.

Come together in many of the same principles that we have where for particularly emphasizing Open Access and to some degree maybe maybe another important principle is the Community driven nature of what we're doing that you know, we really responding to people in Aphasiology child language influences studies in conversation analysis trying to make tools that are specific to that that type of Community interest, and really.
Well, some of these projects actually are run by some of the leaders of those communities.
For example, Aphasia Bank is run by not run by, but is sort of motivated by Audrey Holland who's a you know, great aphasia researcher and and and so on, OK?
We have a standard format for all the data which makes it rather easier to do analysis of every piece of data is in this chat format with, for which there is an XML.
Very tight definition can be validated, and so on, and converted also to the phenology level.
The phenology analysis, and fun.
There's a program called Fan is completely integrated in with the XML for the chat, which is the more transcription oriented.
And as I say, all these transcripts as much as possible, are linked to media.
They're also tagged and also.
Grammatically analyzed with dependency parsing.
The the data can be interoperable with arelon prot thing called salt, which I imagine you guys don't use, but it's in speech and hearing it's them a major format.
The honest corpus analysis system, formats for ASR, we're working with Florian Metze at CMU who uses these quality based speech.
Kitchen set up and we're also dealing with a system called Lena that has 24 hour a day recording setup.
So and within our fan project, which is part of Clan, we've actually incorporated all of product so it actually runs inside inside fan.

I know there was a sort of dispute about should we do, you know handle server or what?

So we have DOI and handle server and all that stuff.

And we really would like to function as much as we can is a clarinet case center really like to be able to provide information on spoken language and this type of transcript analysis that we do, so we hope to be able to really participate in that way.

I think the importance of Open Access is probably the most important message I I am a fan of uniform transcription format.

So my conclusion says we need to of course always expand talk bank.
